paragraph.docTitle:
Phenolics from
Archidendron clypearia (Jack) I.C.Nielsen
protect SH-SY5Y cells against H 2 O 2 -induced oxidative stress

subSection.paragraph:
Xiao-Xiao Huang
a,c, ∗∗
, Guo-Dong Yao
a, ∗∗∗
, Shao-Jiang Song

paragraph.emphasis: Chinese People's Liberation Army Logistics Support Force No. 967 Hospital, Dalian, 116021, People's Republic of China

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O
Phenolics
Neuroprotective activity
Apoptosis
Oxidative stress
A B S T R A C T

Five undescribed phenolics named pithecellobiumin C-G, along with thirteen known ones were isolated from the twigs and leaves of
Archidendron clypearia (Jack) I.C.Nielsen. Their
structures were elucidated based on comprehensive spectroscopic analyses, combined with computer-assisted structure elucidation software (ACD/ Structure Elucidator) and gauge-independent atomic orbitals (GIAO) NMR chemical shift calculations. The absolute configurations were determined by comparison of experimental and calculated specific rotation and ECD curves. These compounds were tested for their neuroprotective activities against H 2 O 2 -induced injury in human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells by MTT assay. Pithecellobiumin C-E exhibited noticeable neuroprotective effect. Further pharmacological study demonstrated that they could prevent cell death through inhibiting the apoptosis induction. Flow cytometry assays also proved that these compounds could attenuate reactive oxygen species (ROS) level and mitochondrial dysfunction in SH-SY5Y cells.
∗ Corresponding author.

∗∗ Corresponding author. Key Laboratory of Computational Chemistry-Based Natural Antitumor Drug Research & Development, School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica , Liaoning province , People's Republic of China .
∗∗∗ Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: xiaoxiao270@163.com (X.-X. Huang), guodong_yao@126.com (G.-D. Yao), songsj99@163.com (S.-J. Song).

caption.paragraph: 1 H NMR Data (400 MHz, δ in ppm, J in Hz) of Compounds 1–5 a .

tableNote.paragraph: a Compounds 1 and 3–5 were recorded in DMSO‑ d . 2 was recorded in

subSection.paragraph: Compound 1 , a deep yellow gum, possessed the molecular formula C 17 H 16 O 8 , as determined by a HRESIMS ion at m/z 349.0918 [M + H] + (calcd for C 17 H 17 O 8 , 349.0918), corresponding to 10 degrees of unsaturation. In the 1 H NMR spectrum of 1 , two sets of aromatic resonances were observed at δ Η 6.20 (1H, d, J = 2.2 Hz, H-6), δ H 6.13 (1H, d, J = 2.2 Hz, H-8) and δ H 7.05 (2H, s, H-3′, H-7′) indicating an asymmetry 4,5,7,9-tetrasubstituted and a symmetrical 2′,4′,5′,6′-tetrasubstituted aromatic ring system, respectively. The resonances at δ H 1.97 (1H, m, H-3a), δ H 1.81 (1H, m, H-3b) and δ H 2.55 (1H, m, H-4a), δ H 2.43 (1H, m, H-4b) exhibited the existence of two methylene groups. Moreover, a methoxy groups at δ H 3.38 (3H, s) and a dioxymethine proton at δ H 5.51 (1H, t, J = 2.7 Hz, H-2) were also observed. The 13 C NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed 17 carbon signals, including 12 aromatic carbons ( δ C 101.1–155.6), one ester carbonyl carbons ( δ C 164.4), two methylenes ( δ C 14.5–25.2), one dioxygenated methine ( δ C 97.6) and one methoxy group ( δ C 55.3). The HMBC ( Fig. 2 ) correlations of H-2,4/ C-9, H-8/C-6,10 and H-6/C-10 were indicative of a chromanyl fragment. The cross peak between OCH 3 and C-2 proved the methoxy group at C-2. Furthermore, the signals of H-3′/C-1′, 5′ and H-7′/C-1′, 5′ revealed the presence of a galloyl group. In the 13 C-NMR of 1 , the signal of C-7 (149.7) was found to have an upfield shift compared to the normal meta-trisubstituded benzene ring, indicating the galloyl group was placed at C-7 of the chromanyl group ( Guo et al., 2007 ). However, this assumption was based on empirical NMR chemical shift prediction due to the paucity of long-range 1 H– 13 C HMBC correlations between these fragments. Hence, ACD/Structure Elucidator (Struc_Eluc; ACD/ Labs, Toronto, ON, Canada ), a computer-assisted structure elucidation software, was used to solve this problem.

After analyzing the spectroscopic data of 1 , two substructures of the galloyl and the chromanyl groups were added manually to accelerate the generation time, and two molecules (ID = 1 and ID = 2) were generated by Correlation Spectroscopy Based Generator. Deviations dN were calculated for chemical shift prediction based on the artificial neural net algorithm. As shown in Fig. S8 , the molecule (ID = 2) with smaller values represented the more acceptable structure for 1 . Additionally, 13 C NMR calculations based on density functional theory (DFT) were performed at the mPW1PW91/6-311 + G (d, p) level with the polarizable continuum model (PCM) in DMSO‑ d 6 solvent. As shown in Fig. 3A , the DP4+ application suggested the most probable structure was the molecule with 100% probability.

The absolute configuration of 1 was elucidated by comparison between the experimental and calculated ECD and the specific rotation value using quantum mechanical calculations. The observation of a positive Cotton effect at 213 nm in the experimental ECD spectrum matched well with the calculated one for the 1 S configuration ( Fig. 4 ), which was consistent with the conclusion drawn by comparison of its specific rotation [ α ]20 D +10.0 ( c 0.5, MeOH) with the calculated value [ α ]20 D +102.5 ( c 0.5, MeOH). Thus, compound 1 was determined and named as (1 S )-pithecellobiumin C ( Fig. 1 ).

Compound 2 possessed the molecular formula C 18 H 16 O 8 based on the HRESIMS data of 383.0739 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 18 H 16 O 8 Na, 383.0737). Detailed comparison between the NMR data of 1 and 2 revealed their structural similarity. The 1 H NMR of 2 showed the absence of a methoxy and the existence of a methyl at δ H 2.25 (3H, s, H- 2″). The 13 C NMR showed the existence of a methyl [C-2′′ ( δ C 26.2)], a ketone [C-1′′ ( δ C 210.0)] and an oxygenated methine [C-2 ( δ C 81.5)] in 2 rather than the methoxy group ( δ C 55.3) and the dioxygenated methine ( δ C 97.6) in 1 . This evidence combined with the key HMBC crosspeaks from H-2″ to C-2 and H-3 to C-1″ indicated that an acetyl group was linked to C- 2 in 2 . The position of the galloyl ester group was elucidated by the combination of Struc-Eluc (Fig. S20) and DFT calculations of NMR chemical shifts ( Fig. 3B ). The structure of ID = 2 showed better similarity to the experimental data and suggested that the galloyl unit was placed at C-7 ( δ C 151.7). By comparing the calculated and experimental ECD spectra, the absolute configuration of 2 was determined to be 3 S ( Fig. 4 ). Additionally, the observed specific rotation [ α ]20 D -16.0 ( c 0.1, MeOH) and calculated value [ α ]20 D -33.0 ( c 0.1, MeOH) displayed the same result as ECD experiment. Thus, 2 was asigned as (3 S )-pithecellobiumin D.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Key HMBC correlations of compounds 1–5 .
Fig. 3. Linear correlations between the scaled calculated and experimental 13 C NMR chemical shifts and statistical DP4+ parameters for compounds 1–3 (A–C).
Fig. 4. Experimental and calculated ECD spectrum of compounds 1 and 2 .

subSection.paragraph: Pithecellobiumin E ( 3 ) showed a sodium adduct ion at 481.0741 [M + Na] + in HRESIMS, corresponding to a molecular formula of C 22 H 18 O 11 (calcd for C 22 H 18 O 11 Na, 481.0741). The NMR data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) at δ H 7.05 (2H, s, H-3′, H-7′), 6.12 (2H, s, H-3, 5) and δ C 100.1 (C-3, 5), 111.4 (C-1), 149.4 (C-4), 156.4 (C-2, 6), 109.0 (C-3′, 7′), 118.4 (C-2′), 139.3 (C-5′), δ C 145.8 (C-4′, 6′) showed typical signals of a galloyl segment and a 5,9-dihydroxy-benzene. In addition, two ortho-coupling signals at δ H 2.76 (2H, t, J = 8.4 Hz, H-7), 2.92 (2H, t, J = 8.4 Hz, H-8) and δ H 6.98 (2H, s, H-2″, H-6″) indicated two adjacent methylenes and a symmetrical 1″,3″,4″,5″-tetrasubstituted aromatic ring system, respectively. In HMBC spectrum, correlations of H-8/C-1, H-7/C-9 and H-2″, 6′′/C-9 indicated the substituent group at C-1 of 3 as shown in Fig. 2 . The three aromatic rings in 3 were symmetrical, which suggested the location of galloyl moiety might be C-4 or C-9. The Struc-Eluc and 13 C NMR calculations experiments suggested the certain placement of galloyl at C-7 (Figs. S28 and 3C) is consistent with the observed 13 C NMR upfield diamagnetic shift. Therefore, the structure of compound 3 was determined.

Pithecellobiumin F ( 4 ) was ascertained to have a molecule at m/z 387.0674 [M + Na] + in the HRESIMS data, which consist with the molecular formula, C 17 H 16 O 9 (calcd for C 17 H 16 O 9 Na, 387.0687). Its NMR data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) was found to be similar to that of 3 . The difference is the presence of a methoxy at δ H 3.60 (3H, s, 9-OCH 3 ) in 4 instead of the phenyl moiety in 3 . Moreover, an ester carbonyl at δ C 173.3 in 4 was instead of the ketone carbon ( δ C 198.5) in 3 , which indicated that the methoxy group might connect to C-9 and formed a methyl ester. The result was further confirmed by the HMBC crosspeaks of OCH 3 /C-9, H-8/C-1 and H-7/C-2, 6, 9. The galloyl group was located at C-4 due to the both symmetrical benzene rings.

The HRESIMS spectrum of compound 5 exhibited a sodium adduct ion at m/z 373.0532 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 16 H 14 O 9 Na, 373.0530) corresponding to the molecular formula of C 16 H 14 O 9 . The NMR data were similar to those of 4 except for the peaks in the high field, which only showed a singlet [ δ H 3.48 (2H, s, H-7)] in 5 rather than the two ortho-coupling methylenes signals in 4 . These observations indicated a methylene unit reduced from 4 and was further confirmed by the HMBC correlations of H-7/C-2 and OCH 3 /C-8. The downfield chemical shifts of H-7 indicated that the methylene located between the benzene ring and the methoxyacyl group. As a result, compound 5 was determined and named as pithecellobiumin G.

caption.paragraph: 13 C NMR Data (100 MHz, δ in ppm, J in Hz) of Compounds 1–5 a .

heading.emphasis: 2.2. Neuroprotective effect of compounds in SH-SY5Y cells

subSection.paragraph:
As an important ROS contributor, hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 ) was used to induce injury in SH-SY5Y cells, which offered a suitable model system in vitro to evaluate neuroprotective activity. As depicted in Fig. 5 , H
2 O 2
decreased the cell viability to 63.6%, compared with the control. After co-cultureing with compounds at different concentrations, the H 2 O 2 -decreaced cell viability was generally restored. Among them, compounds 1–3 , 10 , 12 and 14 exhibited pronounced neuroprotective effects, with the cell survival rate of 111.4, 115.5, 101.7, 90.3, 95.8 and 96.3%, respectively. The protective potent of 1–3 displayed higher efficacy than 10 , 12 and 14 , which indicated that the However, pretreatment with compounds 1 , 2 and 3 (50 μ M) significantly reduced the percentage of apoptotic cells to 12.1%, 16.7% and 16.8%, respectively. Taken together, the result demonstrated that these three compounds could rescue H 2 O 2 -induced SH-SY5Y cells death by inhibiting the cell apoptosis.

paragraph.tableNote: a Compounds 1 and 3–5 were recorded in DMSO‑ d . 2 was recorded in 6 methanol- d 4 .

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. Neuroprotective effects of compounds 1–18 on H 2 O 2 -damaged SH-SY5Y cells using MTT assay. Data are presented as means ± S.D. (n = 3). * p <0.05, ** p <0.01, *** p <0.001 as compared to model.

subSection.paragraph: galloyl moiety might improve protective potent. For the series of common flavonoids, compound 14 with hydroxy groups at C-7, 8 and C-3′, 4′ is associated with a high protective potency. However, when it was substituted with methoxy or galloyl, the cell viability was reduced about 20% ( 6 : 69.7%, 15 : 75.8%). A comparison of the structures and activities of compounds with galloyl substitution (compounds 1–7 ), suggested that the opening of C-ring was important for the activity. Nevertheless, when B-ring was displaced by methoxy or formyl group and C-ring was recyclized (compounds 1–2 ), the neuroprotective activities were further increased compared to their analogue 3 . Above all, 1–3 were the most promising compounds and they were selected for the further study.

heading.emphasis: 2.3. Protective effects of compounds against apoptosis

subSection.paragraph:
Consequently, the further mechanism of the protective activities of compounds
1–3 in
H 2 O 2 -injured SH-SY5Y cells were investigated. As illustrated in Fig. 6 , treatment with H 2 O 2 group effectively increased the cell apoptotic rate to 33.23% compared with control group.

heading.emphasis: 2.4. Protective effect of compounds against the oxidative stress

subSection.paragraph: As reported, excessive ROS irreversibly injuries DNA and lipids, and ultimately leads to cell apoptosis ( Xu et al., 2017 ). H 2 O 2 , a common oxidant, could induce oxidative damage and increase the levels of ROS in cells ( Reshmitha et al., 2017 ). In next experiment, the capacity of compounds 1–3 to rescue H 2 O 2 -induced oxidative stress was investigated. The flow cytometric analysis showed that H 2 O 2 exposure effectively increased DCF positive ratio. But compounds 1–3 could ameliorate the situation prominently and the ROS levels were similar to control group (Fig. 7). These results suggested that compounds 1–3 reduced H 2 O 2 -induced ROS accumulation in SH-SY5Y cells, which might be arising from the restoration of the antioxidant defense system.

heading.emphasis: 2.5. Protective effect of compounds against the mitochondrial damage

subSection.paragraph: Mitochondrial dysfunction is proved to be one of the most emerging pathological process in neurodegenerative disorder ( Lee, 2016 ). It is reported that, mitochondria is an important source of reactive oxygen species, and the increased ROS intensifies mitochondria dysfunction and cell injury ( Sariki et al., 2016 ). The decreased mitochondrial membrane potential (ΔΨm) was regarded as a significant indicator to denote mitochondrial dysfunction. As the result in Fig. 8 , the fluorescence intensity ratio between green and red significantly increased after treatment with H 2 O 2 treatment, which suggested that H 2 O 2 could induce mitochondrial dysfunction. This phenomenon was reversed in compound group, the percent of ΔΨm loss cells of which was reduced to 18.4%, 11.8% and 11.2%, respectively. The results suggested that compound 1–3 could protect SH-SY5Y cells from mitochondrial dysfunction induced by H 2 O 2 .

caption.paragraph: Fig. 6. Effects of compounds 1–3 to attenuate apoptosis of H 2 O 2 -treated SH-SY5Y cells. Cells were pretreated with 1, 2, 3 (50 μ M), then treated with H 2 O 2 (200 μ M) for 4 h. Flow cytometry was used to determine the apoptotic ratio after Annexin V-FITC/PI staining. Data were shown as mean ± SD from three separate experiments. ## P <0.01 compared with the control group, * P <0.05, ** P <0.01 compared with the H O group.

subSection.paragraph: Fig. 7. Compounds 1–3 attenuated H 2 O 2 -induced oxidative stress. In the absence or presence of 1 , 2 , 3 (50 μ M), then SH-SY5Y cells were incubated with H 2 O 2 (200 μ M) for 4h. Cells were detected using H 2 DCFH-DA staining by flow cytometry. ## P <0.01 compared with the control group, ** P <0.01 compared with the H 2 O 2 group.

In conclusion, five undescribed galloylated phenolics (pithecellobiumin C-G), along with thirteen known compounds were isolated from the twigs and leaves of
A. clypearia
. The substituted position of galloyl group was determined by the synergistic combination of CASE and DFT methods, when traditional spectroscopic methods could not offer enough evidence. The neuroprotective effects against H 2 O 2 -induced injury in SH-SY5Y cells of all isolated compounds were tested by MTT assay. The results suggested that compounds 1–3 possessed noticeable neuroprotective effect. Subsequently, flow cytometry assays also showed that these three compounds exerted protective activity through inhibiting cell apoptosis which probably implicated in reducing ROS production and mitochondria damage. This study provided an inspiration of searching for undescribed compounds with neuroprotective activity from
A. clypearia
.
The information of the experimental procedures was described in the Supporting Information.

The twigs and leaves of
Archidendron clypearia (Jack) I.C.Nielsen (Leguminosae)
were collected from Huanjiang ( Guangxi , China ) with the location “ E108°26′ , N24°83′”. The plant was genetically identified by Professor Jincai Lu at Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. A voucher specimen (DG-20150529) has been deposited in the herbarium of the Department of Natural Products Chemistry , Shenyang Pharmaceutical University
.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 8. Compounds 1–3 reduced mitochondrial dysfunction in H 2 O 2 -induced SH-SY5Y cells. Cells were pretreated with 1 , 2 , 3 (50 μ M), then treated with H 2 O 2 (200 μ M) for 4h. The loss of ΔΨm was determined by JC-1 staining and measured by flow cytometric analysis. ## P <0.01 compared with the control group, ** P <0.01, * P <0.05 compared with the H 2 O 2 group.

subSection.paragraph:
The twigs and leaves of
A. clypearia
( 50 kg ) were extracted three times with 70% ethanol for 2h. The solid-liquid ratio is 1:10. The extract was concentrated under reduced pressure to give 1.8 kg extractum. Then, the extractum was partitioned between ethyl acetate (3 L) and water (1.5 L). The EtOAc partition was initially subjected to column chromatography (silica gel 200–300 mesh) eluting with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (50:1, 30:1, 15:1, 10:1, 5:1, 1:1, v/v ) to obtain fractions A-D. Fraction C ( 827 g ) was chromatographed on a D101 macroporous resin column eluting with water and increasing amounts of EtOH to get fractions C1 and C2. Fr. C1 ( 500 g ) was fractionated on silica gel column eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (50:1–1:1, v/v ) to provide four fractions, among which Fr. C1-2 ( 130 g ) was subjected to a HP-20 macroporous resin column (EtOH/H 2 O; 10:90; 60:40; 90:10, v/v ) to yield three fractions named as C1-2-1 ( 30g ), C1-2-2 ( 70g ), C1-2-3 ( 25g ), respectively. The three fractions above were then carried on ODS columns, using EtOH–H 2 O (from 1:9 to 10:0) as the elution system and cross merging to obtain fractions G-J, respectively. G ( 27 g ) and H ( 53 g ) were further chromatographed on silica column with the mobile phase CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (from 30:1 to 1:1) to provide fractions Fr. G1-G10 and Fr. H1–H8, respectively. G8 ( 233 mg ) was applied to RP-C18 CC (MeOH–H 2 O, 35:65, v/v ), then subsequently purified through preparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O, 20:80, v/ v ) to obtain compounds 2 ( 17.5 mg ) and 3 ( 22.9 mg ). G5 ( 498 mg ) was purified to afford compound 5 ( 240.8 mg ) in the same way. Compounds 1 ( 17.5 mg ) and 4 ( 97.2 mg ) was isolated from H1 ( 299.5 mg ) via semipreparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O, 22:78, v/v ).

(1S)-pithecellobiumin C (1): Deep yellow gum; []
D
20 -16.0 ( c 0.10, CH 3 OH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 210 (2.78), 280 (2.97) nm; IR (KBr) ν max 3394, 2853, 1716, 1604, 1441, 1202, 1007, 863, 758 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 383.0739 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 18 H 16 O 8 Na, 383.0737).

pithecellobiumin E (3): Yellow gum; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 207 (2.36), 290 (3.48) nm; IR (KBr) ν max 3404, 1606, 1450, 1341, 1205, 1036, 858, 734, 457 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 481.0741 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 22 H 18 O 11 Na, 481.0741).

pithecellobiumin F (4): Deep yellow gum; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 240 (2.43), 280 (2.69) nm; IR (KBr) ν max 3419, 2853, 2375, 1701, 1613, 1356, 1202, 1034, 865, 623 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 387.0674 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 17 H 16 O 9 Na, 387.0687).

pithecellobiumin G (5): Yellow gum; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 240 (2.63), 281 (3.46) nm; IR (KBr) ν max 3405, 1721, 1614, 1440, 1350, 1200, 999, 865, 759 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 373.0532 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 16 H 14 O 9 Na, 373.0530).
The NMR, OR and ECD computational details were listed in the
Supporting Information.
The protective effects of all polyphenols ( 1–18 ) were evaluated in H 2 O 2 -induced SH-SY5Y cells via MTT assay according to the previously reported procedure ( Qi et al., 2018 ).
Compounds 1–3 with obvious activity were further examined for apoptosis inhibition effect by annexin V-FITC/PI double staining assay using procedure previously ( Qi et al., 2018 ).
The ROS levels in SH-SY5Y cells treated by 1–3 were detected using H 2 DCF-DA fluorescent dye by flow cytometer as methods reported before ( Wang et al., 2018a ).

Cells treated by compounds 1–3 were evaluated for the mitochondrial membrane potential (ΔΨm) by JC-1 assay kit. The experimental procedure carried out as the reported literature ( Zhou et al., 2018 ).

The authors declare that no conflict of interest exists in the submission of this manuscript entitled “Phenolics from Archidendron clypearia (Jack) I.C.Nielsen. protect SH-SY5Y cells against H2O2-induced oxidative stress”, and manuscript is read and approved by all authors for publication. I would like to declare on behalf of my co-authors that the work described was original research that has not been published previously, and not under consideration for publication elsewhere, in whole or in part.

This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (81502954) and the Career Development Support Plan for Young and Middle-aged Teachers in Shenyang Pharmaceutical University (ZQN2018006).
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2020.112414.
